description.compact: If the query should have the "slaveOkay" flag set, which allows reads on the secondary (secondaries are, by default, just for backup and not queried). Can be overridden with MongoCursor::slaveOkay.

docblock.description: If the query should have the "slaveOkay" flag set, which allows reads on the secondary (secondaries are, by default, just for backup and not queried). Can be overridden with MongoCursor::slaveOkay.

description.compact: Set timeout in milliseconds for all database responses. Use -1 to wait forever. Can be overridden with MongoCursor::timeout. This does not cause the MongoDB server to cancel the operation; it only instructs the driver to stop waiting for a response and throw a MongoCursorTimeoutException after a set time.
Adds a top-level key/value pair to a query

docblock.description: This is an advanced function and should not be used unless you know what you're doing.

description.compact: Sets whether this cursor will wait for a while for a tailable cursor to return more data
Limits the number of elements returned in one batch.
Create a new cursor
Counts the number of results for this query
Returns the current element
Checks if there are results that have not yet been sent from the database

docblock.description: The database sends responses in batches of documents, up to 4MB of documents per response. This method checks if the database has more batches or if the result set has been exhausted.

description.compact: Execute the query.
Return an explanation of the query, often useful for optimization and debugging
Sets the fields for a query

docblock.description: Fields are specified by "fieldname" : bool. TRUE indicates that a field should be returned, FALSE indicates that it should not be returned. You can also use 1 and 0 instead of TRUE and FALSE.

description.compact: Advances the cursor to the next result, and returns that result
Get the read preference for this query
Checks if there are any more elements in this cursor
Gives the database a hint about the query
Sets whether this cursor will timeout

docblock.description: After remaining idle on the server for some amount of time, cursors, by default, "die." This is generally the behavior one wants. The database cleans up a cursor once all of its results have been sent to the client, but if the client doesn't request all of the results, the cursor will languish there, taking up resources. Thus, after a few minutes, the cursor "times out" and the database assumes the client has gotten everything it needs and cleans up its the cursor's resources.

description.compact: Gets information about the cursor's creation and iteration
Returns the current result's _id, or its index within the result set
Limits the number of results returned
Sets a server-side timeout for this query
Advances the cursor to the next result, and returns that result
If this query should fetch partial results from mongos if a shard is down

docblock.description: This option allows mongos to send partial query results if a shard is unreachable. This is only applicable when running a sharded MongoDB cluster and connecting to a mongos.

description.compact: Clears the cursor
Returns the cursor to the beginning of the result set
Sets arbitrary flags in case there is no method available the specific flag
Set the read preference for this query
Skips a number of results
Sets whether this query can be done on a secondary [deprecated]

docblock.description: This method is deprecated since version 1.5.0. Instead, please use MongoCursor::setReadPreference and .

description.compact: Use snapshot mode for the query

docblock.description: Use snapshot mode for the query. Snapshot mode ensures that a document will not be returned more than once because an intervening write operation results in a move of the document. Documents inserted or deleted during the lifetime of the cursor may or may not be returned, irrespective of snapshot mode.

description.compact: Sorts the results by given fields
Sets whether this cursor will be left open after fetching the last results

docblock.description: Mongo has a feature known as tailable cursors which are similar to the Unix "tail -f" command.

description.compact: Sets a client-side timeout for this query
Checks if the cursor is reading a valid result.
